quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Alaska and Year
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, peak, salmon. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What was the original name of Mt. McKinley?
In what year did the capital of Alaska move from Sitka to Juneau?
Psychologists say that more of our fantasies are about money than sex.
There are two active volcanoes in Lake Clark National Park at the North End of the Alaskan Peninsula.
How did the City of Juneau in Alaska get its name?

options.text: It was named after Joe Juneau.
The area was discovered in June.
It was named after a lady.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: It was named after Joe Juneau.

questions.question: In what year did Alaska become a state?
This is an island country consisting of almost one thousand islands, it is located east of Papua New Guinea and its capital is Honiara.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Solomon Islands

questions.question: There are living creatures beneath and inside the ice of glaciers in Alaska.
Which gold rush came first?
This republic is located in northwestern South America, it is named after a European explorer and its capital city is Bogota.
Salmon from the Kenai River must weigh at least 25 pounds more than salmon caught elsewhere in Alaska to qualify as a trophy.
In this year, the First Bank of the United States was chartered.
What is the highest peak in the United States?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mt. McKinley

questions.question: This island country is located east of the Caribbean Sea, it was a colony of the United Kingdom until 1966. Its flag features a trident.
Who was the first person to stand on  the summit of Mt. McKinley?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Walter Harper in 1913

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Country and Central Park
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, ridges, bills. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The homeland of the Mayans stretched from Mexicos Yucatan peninsula southward into Belize and what other country?

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis

questions.question: Which country is home to the huge and spectacular statue of Jesus Christ the Redeemer, constructed in 1931?
Central Park is the largest city park in the United States.

The Federal Reserve System issues notes through its 12 districts. Each of the numbers from one to twelve corresponds to a certain district. In addition to numbers, the districts have corresponding letters as well. Only one of the following pairs (district - its number - its letter) is correct.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Boston - 1- A

questions.question: Managua is the capital of this country whose currency is called cordoba.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Woodrow Wilson

questions.question: The ridges on the sides of coins are called reedings or millings. The dime has this number of such ridges.
This is the percentage of bills in circulation, that are $1 notes.
Which country was terribly devastated by Hurricane Mitch in 1998?
On the back of the $50 bill you can see this building.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: U.S. Capitol

questions.question: If you had $1 million in $1 bills then the million would weigh this much.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 2,041 pounds (925 kg)

questions.question: This is the time on the Independence Hall clock on the back of the $100 bill.
Its a beautiful Saturday morning and you want to explore Central Park with your family. Which form of transportation should your family NOT plan on using?

quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, km, independence. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This Italian town is famous for the Palio, which is a horse race around the Piazza del Campo held between 17 Contrade, or city neighbourhoods.

What is the capital city of Malta, a small island nation in the Mediterranean?
What is the capital of Poland?
Which country elected Felipe Calderon President on September 6, 2006?
Which of the following countries is located in Central America?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Costa Rica

questions.question: This port of Athens is the largest port in Europe in terms of passengers.
Which South American country has two capitals, named La Paz and Sucre?
What is the capital of Iceland?
This river, over 1000 km in length, flows through Spain  and Portugal.
This northern English city is noted for a Viking Centre, a street of mediaeval shops known as The Shambles,  and a famous Minster.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Puerto Rico

questions.question: The lost city of the Incas, Machu Picchu stands high above the gorges of the Urubamba, which is located in this country.
Cobh, a town in Cork Harbour, Ireland , was known by this name until the founding of the Irish Free State in 1922.

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: November and Baltic Sea
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, title, independence. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: On November 18 in 1820, US navigator Nathaniel Palmer became the first American to land on  Antarctica. Why did he go there?

options.text: There was no more meat on his ship and he was going after whale meat.
It was a total mistake - he was trying to get to Patagonia in Argentina.
His rudder was broken and his ship, the Hero, just sailed due South.
He wanted to hunt for seals.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He wanted to hunt for seals.

questions.question: The Baltic Sea, bound by Scandinavia and Eastern Europe, has a connection to the Atlantic Ocean via the North Sea. There is also an artificial canal that links the Baltic Sea with the Arctic Ocean. Almost 200,000 people perished building this canal in the 1930s during Stalins GULAG years. It links the Baltic Sea with this small sea in Russia.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: White Sea

questions.question: Who directed Steamboat Willie, the first fully synchronized sound cartoon with Mickey Mouse, which was released on November 18 in 1928?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks

questions.question: Which comic strip, written and illustrated by Bill Watterson, began on November 18 in 1985?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Calvin and Hobbs

questions.question: The Brussels American School (US Department of Defense School) and Brussels Airport are located in

There are many rivers that flow into the Baltic Sea. The Daugava in Russia, Belarus, and Latvia is the longest ( 1,020km ). Another river, however, has the highest water discharge while being only 74 km in length. In this aspect, it is is the third largest river in Europe after Volga and Danube. Name it.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Neva, Russia

questions.question: The Baltic Sea connects to the North Sea via several natural straits of different sizes between Denmark on one side and Sweden and Norway on the other. Which of the following is NOT a strait between the two seas?
This Baltic country celebrates its Independence Day on November 18th. The people there speak an Indo-European language and its largest city is not Vilna.
The first book printed on press was produced on November 18 in what year?
On November 18 in 1913, Lincoln Beachy became the first American to perform which one of the following?

options.text: Double inside one and one-hale dive

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Loop -the-loop in a plane.

questions.question: What is the title of Mark Twains first story, which was printed in the New York Saturday Evening Post

options.text: The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County
A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthurs Court

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County

questions.question: There are nine countries that surround the Baltic Sea. Some of their capitals are port-cities located on the Baltic Sea, its gulfs, bays, or straits. Which Baltic capital has access to the sea only via a river system?
According to legend, on November 18 in 1307 William Tell shot an arrow through an apple on top of his sons head. Tell is a national hero of which country?
On November 18 in 1978, Jim Jones and his followers committed mass suicide in Jonestown. Where was Jonestown?
Which was the second Western Hemisphere country (after the USA) to gain its independence after winning an important battle on November 18 in 1803?

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: October and Actor
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, actor, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This notable U.S. president, born on October 27, 1858, has his face carved in Mount Rushmore.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Theodore Roosevelt

questions.question: A disaster that took the lives of 852 people occurred in September of 1994 when the ferry ship named after this country sank in the Baltic Sea.

Arguably, the worst ship sinking in terms of loss of life in history occurred in the Baltic Sea. The Soviet captain Alexander Marinesko, the man Hitler called his personal enemy, sent almost 9,000 people, mostly civilians, down to the bottom of the sea when he torpedoed this German ship.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wilhelm Gustloff

questions.question: This city, founded in 1703, is the largest city on the Baltic Sea in terms of population.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: St Petersburg, Russia

questions.question: This famous movie actress was born on October 28, 1967. She is famous for movies like Something To Talk About and Oceans Eleven.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Julia Roberts

questions.question: This actress, born on October 1, 1935,  won an Academy Award and a Golden Globe for a classic musical movie in 1964.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Julie Andrews

questions.question: He was the second U.S. President and was born on October 30, 1735.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Adams

questions.question: This actor, born on October 18,1987, starred in the famous Disney Channel movie High School Musical.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Zac Efron

questions.question: Born on October 12, 1970, this actor is widely known for portraying Mike Seaver in a popular 80s television series.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kirk Cameron

questions.question: Gotland, the largest island in the Baltic Sea, is also a province of this Baltic country.
His birthdate is October 4, 1924. He was a heroic actor and president of the National Rifle Association for five years.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Charlton Heston

questions.question: The Kaliningrad region belongs to the Russian Federation, although it is separated from the Russian territory and borders Lithuania and Poland. Right before and during WWII the region was a part of this European country.

Some countries around the Baltic Sea have very similar culture, history and language. The Prussian language that was a part of the Baltic language group is now extinct. What are the two remaining languages of the Baltic group?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Latvian and Lithuanian

questions.question: This businessman, born on October 11, 1844, is known for opening one of the most famous condiment companies in America.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Henry John Heinz

questions.question: Born on October 26, 1947, this previous First Lady is also known for being Senator of New York.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hillary Rodham Clinton

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Generation and Company
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, people, independence. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which of the following races is always held in July and lasts approximately 3 weeks?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Le Tour de France

questions.question: What company produced the famous race car Sport Kurz between 1928 and 1932?
Which Italian automobile manufacturer was set up in 1910 and has been part of the FIAT Group since 1986?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alfa Romeo

questions.question: The character Short Round drove a replica of this car in the opening scenes of Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom, a film released in 1984. It was a United States make of car. The company existed from 1930 to 1936.
What Mustang-inspired model did the Ford Motor company release in 1964? It was meant to be affordable, attractive and oriented towards the youth.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pony Car

questions.question: Frederick Henry Royce and Charles Stewart Rolls were the engineers who built the first  Rolls-Royce motor cars. What was the name of the first generation of Rolls-Royce?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rolls-Royce pre Silver Ghost

questions.question: Who was awarded the Car Engineer of the Century on December 18, 1999 in Las Vegas?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ferdinand Porsche

questions.question: What make was the official state limousine of many US Presidents, including Franklin D. Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy?
Deborah Harry and Dan Aykroyd are both Canadians born on the same day in July.
Each generation of BMW has been signified by an e-code - the letter E and a number.  Which was the first generation of BMW cars?
What Swedish automobile maker produced a vehicle for the Swedish Army in 1959?
Which of the following extraordinarily tall people died on July 15, 1940?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Robert Wadlow

questions.question: The month of July is named after Julius Caesar.
The Declaration of Independence consists of 2 pages.
The first vehicles that can be considered automobiles were built by Karl Benz in 1888. What do you call the era of the first automobiles?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Veteran era
